recipe.name: piedmontese salad
recipe.summary: Impossible to miss the Piedmont salad! This great classic of French cuisine, however, as its name suggests, originated in Italy. It takes its name from the region of north-western Italy called Piedmont. Today this unctuous mixture of tomatoes, potatoes, eggs, pickles and ham, all closely linked by a gourmet mayonnaise is present everywhere: in caterers, in small and large restaurants, in bistros, et cetera. A complete recipe to success that has managed to settle permanently to the menu of French gastronomy.

recipe.name: Tart Tatin
recipe.summary: Here is the story without a top of a caramelized apple pie of legend, which is cooked upside down but is eaten at the place. Originally from Sologne in the 19th century, Tarte Tatin owes its name to two sisters: Caroline and Stéphanie Tatin. According to the versions, the legend says that the recipe would be the result of an awkwardness (the pie would have been reversed and then cooked upside down), an oversight (the apples would have cooked too long) or would simply be the reproduction of A former Solognote specialty. However, the victim of its success, it exported to Paris in 1926. Served for the first time in the restaurant Maxim's, it has since become a classic French tables!

step.sentence: To make this recipe for tart tatin, start by preparing all the ingredients.
Peel the apples,
Cut them in half,
And remove the cores with the tip of an office knife.
In a tart tart pan, put the butter to melt.
Add powdered sugar in fine rain.
Mix gently with a spatula,
Until the two ingredients are thoroughly mixed.
Make a brown caramel. Be careful not to leave it too dark, it would give a bitter taste to your pie.
Leave to color the caramel according to your convenience(more or less clear). Remove from fire.
Arrange half-apples on the warm caramel. Keep them at the start with your fingers to keep them vertical,

Then wedge them against each other. Thoroughly clamp them together. Think they will reduce to cooking! If apples remain, prune them into smaller pieces and arrange them on top. Add cinnamon(optional).
Cook for about 10 minutes over high heat. Thus, the apples will start to cook and they will be well impregnated with caramel.
Fleure your work plan. Lower the broken dough using a rolling pin,
3 or 4 mm thick into a disc slightly larger than the diameter of the dish.
To make sure of the size of the dough disc, here I use a pie circle that is slightly larger(2 to 3 cm on each side) than the tatin tart mold, and I cut the dough all around.
Take the dough disc gently with your hands and place it on the still warm apples.
Tuck the edges of dough that protrude inside the mold. Do not hesitate to press them in with your fingers.
Press with the palms of the hands to make the apple paste adhere well(without drilling) and arrange the apples in the bottom of the mold.
With the tip of a galley knife, make a small chimney so that the steam can escape during cooking.
Bake in a hot oven(180 to 200 degrees celsius) until the dough is fully cooked. The dough is cooked and the caramel begins to rise on the sides. After cooking, remove the mold from the oven.
Cover with a serving dish with a light edge to collect the juice.
Catch the two dishes simultaneously with two dry dishcloths,
And return the assembly in a rapid but controlled movement.
Beware of splashing!
Lift the still warm cooking dish and you can finally discover this delicious apple tatin pie.
It will preferably use lukewarm accompanied by a tablespoon of cream or a ball of vanilla ice cream.
